scenarios.title: Pulled over by police
rightsPlain: You have the right to remain silent.
You may refuse consent to a search of your vehicle.
You can ask why you were stopped.
You may ask if you are free to leave once the stop is complete.
You have the right to an attorney if you are detained or arrested.
sayThis: I do not consent to any searches.
Am I being detained, or am I free to leave?
I would like to speak to a lawyer.
steps: Safely pull over and turn off your engine.
Keep your hands visible on the steering wheel.
Provide license, registration, and insurance if requested.
You do not have to answer investigative questions.
If asked to search your car, you may refuse verbally.
Do not physically interfere with officers.
If detained or arrested, clearly ask for a lawyer and remain silent.

legalBasis.title: 4th Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Protects against unreasonable searches and seizures. You generally may refuse consent to a vehicle search unless there is probable cause or a warrant.

legalBasis.title: 5th Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Protects against self-incrimination. You are not required to answer questions beyond basic identification.

legalBasis.title: 6th Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Guarantees the right to an attorney. Once you ask for a lawyer, questioning should stop.

legalBasis.title: 1st Amendment
legalBasis.summary: In many public settings, recording police is protected as long as you do not interfere.

importantNotes: Say it calmly. Do not argue or raise your voice.
Do not resist physically â€” assert your rights verbally.

scenarios.title: Stopped on foot
rightsPlain: You have the right to remain silent.
You may ask if you are being detained or if you are free to leave.
You do not have to consent to a search of your body or belongings.
If you are detained or arrested, you have the right to a lawyer.
In many public places, you may record police interactions as long as you do not interfere.
sayThis: Am I being detained, or am I free to leave?
I do not consent to any searches.
I would like to speak to a lawyer.
steps: Stop moving and keep your hands visible.
Stay calm and do not run or resist.
Ask clearly if you are being detained or free to leave.
If free to leave, walk away calmly.
If detained, remain silent and do not answer questions.
You may refuse consent to searches verbally.
If arrested, ask for a lawyer and stop speaking.

legalBasis.title: 4th Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Protects against unreasonable searches and seizures. Police may briefly detain you only if they have reasonable suspicion.

legalBasis.title: 5th Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Protects your right to remain silent. You are not required to answer investigative questions.

legalBasis.title: 6th Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Guarantees the right to an attorney. Once you request a lawyer, questioning should stop.

legalBasis.title: 1st Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Protects speech and, in many public settings, the right to record police activity without interference.

importantNotes: If youâ€™re free to leave, leave calmly â€” donâ€™t keep talking.
Do not physically interfere â€” assert your rights verbally.

scenarios.title: Police at my door
rightsPlain: You do not have to open the door unless police have a warrant.
You may ask to see the warrant before opening the door.
You have the right to remain silent.
You do not have to consent to officers entering your home.
If you are detained or arrested, you have the right to a lawyer.
sayThis: I do not consent to any searches or entry.
I would like to speak to a lawyer.
steps: Stay inside and keep the door closed.
Ask who they are and why they are there.
Ask clearly if they have a warrant.
If they do not have a warrant, you may refuse entry.
If they do have a warrant, ask them to slide it under the door or show it through a window.
Do not answer questions beyond identifying yourself if required.
If officers enter, state clearly that you do not consent and remain silent.
If detained or arrested, ask for a lawyer and stop speaking.

legalBasis.title: 4th Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Protects against unreasonable searches and seizures. Police generally need a warrant or a recognized exception to enter your home.

legalBasis.title: 5th Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Protects your right to remain silent. You are not required to answer investigative questions.

legalBasis.title: 6th Amendment
legalBasis.summary: Guarantees the right to an attorney. Once you request a lawyer, questioning should stop.

importantNotes: Speak through the door if possible.
Do not physically block officers â€” assert your rights verbally.
